column1: Constitutional and Administrative Law by Hilaire Barnett (9th Edition) at
“Judicial review must be distinguished from an appeal against a decision. The
court and tribunal structure provides a more or less rational appeal structure
for  those  aggrieved  by  a  judicial  decision.  The  appellate  court  will  have  the
power to reconsider the case and to substitute its own decision for that of the
lower court. An appeal may be made on both the law and the facts of the case,
so  full  re-hearing  may  take  place.  Judicial  review,  by  contrast,  is  concerned
solely with the manner in which the decision maker has applied relevant rules:
proceedings- to substitute its judgement for that of the decision-making body to
which powers have been delegated but, rather, to ensure that the adjudicator
has kept within the rules laid down by statute and the common law. In short,
the  role  of  the  courts  in  judicial  review  is  to  exercise  a  supervisory,  not  an
appellate, jurisdiction. Judicial review ‘is not an appeal from a decision, but a
review of the manner in which the decision was made.”
In the instant Application, the Petitioner is challenging the Award marked as
Z1 on the basis, inter-alia, that;
